properties.media:imagetext:
4.
WHEN PONCE de LEON SAILED from PUERTO RICO in 1513 and DISCOVERED FLORIDA
THE SITE OF THIS AIRPORT WAS A TINY ISLAND OF "KEY" from SPANISH CAYO- ISLAND
IT REMAINED SO WHILE the LATER PIONEERS of COCONUT GROVE 3 CENTURIES LATER
OFTEN CAME to the PALM-SHADED BIT of LAND for PICNIC DINNERS - HENCE CAME
THE OLD NAME "DINNER KEY."
THE UNITED STATES WAR DEPT FILLED IN THIE SHALLOW WATERS and MADE
THE KEY A PART of the MAINLAND DURING the WORLD WAR WHEN IT BECAME anACTIVE
NAVY AIR BASE, AT THAT TIME THE PRESENT UNUSED TOWER WAS ERECTED TO
SUPPORT A HUGE, WATER TANK.
LATER THE BASE WAS USED by VARIOUS EARLY COMMERCIAL FLIERS and by the
NEW YORK. RIO and BUENOS AIRES AIRLINE. IN 1930 PAN AMERICAN AIRWAYS TOOK OVER
THIS LINE and the BASE, and MOVED ITS OPERATIONS fros the PAN AMERICAN LAND
FIELD ON 36% ST. MIAMI. PAN AMERICAN BUILT the PRESENT STEEL BULKHEAD.
ADDING 13 ACRES. and RAISED the ENTIRE BASE THREE FEET HIGHER THE AIRPORT NOW
CONTAINS 43 ACRES of LAND and ALMOST UNLIMITED AREAS in BISCAYNE BAY FOR
THE OPERATION OF THE GIANT FLYING BOATS.
FOR THE FIRST TIME in HISTORY, THE UNITED STATES GOVERNMENT DREDGED
HERE A CHANNEL FOR AIRCRAFT, AS the CLIPPER SHIPS DRAW 3 to 5 FT. of WATER. THIS
CHANNEL, SHOWN by the MARKERS, IS 700 FT. WIDE and EXTENDS 1 MILE EASTWARD
FROM THE TERMINAL BUILDING TO DEEPER WATERS Of BISCAYNE BAY.
THIS BASE IS CLOSER TO HAVANA (229 MILES) THAN TO DAYTONA. FLORIDA (257);
CLOSER TO MEXICO (540 MILES DIRECT) THAN ATLANTA (627): NEARER SOUTH AMERICA
(1090 MILES) THAN NEW YORK(1196). HOWEVER. RIO de JANEIRO IS 5951 MILES BY
CLIPPER ROUTE - BUENOS AIRES 7066-MORE THAN DOUBLE THE DISTANCE BETWEEN
NEW YORK and LONDON and FARTHER THAN FROM MIAMI to AFRICA or INDIA.
THIS INTERNATIONAL AIRPORT IS NOW THE WORLD'S MOST ACTIVE COMMERCIAL
MARINE AIR BASE. IT LEADS ALL AMERICAN CITIES AS A PORT OF ENTRY FOR AIR
TRAVELERS FROM FOREIGN PORTS. REGULAR SCHEDULES ARE OPERATED TO
AND FROM THE WEST INDIES, MEXICO. PANAMA and SOUTH AMERICA.
IT IS THE MAIN
AIR GATEWAY BETWEEN THE AMERICAS.
